questions.question: Explain how a pull-down resistor helps in stable button readings.

answers.a: It keeps the pin at LOW when button is not pressed.
answers.c: It makes the button work without wiring.

questions.question: Why does a potentiometer produce varying voltage?

answers.a: Because it changes resistance as you rotate the knob.
answers.d: Because it has multiple output pins.

questions.question: How can we convert LDR analog readings into percentage light intensity?

answers.c: By converting it to digital values.
answers.d: By reading only HIGH or LOW.

questions.question: Write the difference between slider switch and pushbutton.

answers.a: Slider stays in position while pushbutton is momentary.
answers.c: Slider gives analog output while pushbutton gives digital.
answers.d: Pushbutton is ON/OFF while slider is analog.

questions.question: How can debouncing be handled in pushbutton applications?

answers.a: Using delay() or software logic filtering.

questions.question: How does Arduino process analog values internally?

answers.a: It uses a 10-bit ADC to convert voltage into numbers 0–1023.
answers.b: It directly reads voltage without conversion.
answers.c: It converts analog into digital only at HIGH/LOW.
answers.d: It stores analog values in EEPROM.

questions.question: Suggest an application where potentiometer input can be practically used.
Explain why LDR is preferred in automatic lighting systems.

answers.a: Because it changes resistance based on light level.

questions.question: How would you detect long press vs short press in simulation?

answers.a: By measuring how long the button stays pressed using millis().
